body:
One of the differences I see so far, the expression:

``` js
Math.sin(-Math.PI)
```

This returns 0 on Canary and -1.2246063538223773e-16 on Stable (and Node.js v0.10.21, Firefox, and Safari, FWIW).

Broken world map:

[![screen shot 2013-11-17 at 9 12 30 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/1558787/85e16e36-4fab-11e3-8c79-62aebce5a0d1.png)](http://bl.ocks.org/mbostock/raw/4180634/)

I was able to fix most of the artifacts by adding epsilons (somewhat mindlessly) to src/geo/clip-antimeridian. However, this did not eliminate all of the artifacts, and may have inadvertently introduced other problems.

![screen shot 2013-11-17 at 9 12 01 am](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/230541/1558790/ab811948-4fab-11e3-971b-8c1bf03af501.png)

That hack is available in the [fix-resampling-error branch](https://github.com/mbostock/d3/tree/fix-resampling-error). However, I would greatly benefit from @jasondavies’s help on this one.
My guess is this was broken by Chromium’s [new sin, cos and tan implementations](https://codereview.chromium.org/70003004/) using table lookup and spline interpolation.

Related Chromium bug: https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=320097
Earlier related V8 bug: https://code.google.com/p/v8/issues/detail?id=3006
Commit b80997445529f663ccfa51bd887c192037f06058 seems to fix all artifacts. Pull the fix-resampling-error branch if you want to test.

issue.title: Avoid flipping longitude near ±π.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body: When computing the midpoint between two points both at longitude -π, there was a chance that atan2 would return +π rather than -π. Now, we check whether the points to interpolate lie (approximately) on a meridian; if they do, we can approximate by using linear interpolation of longitude rather than atan2. This fixes #1635 which was caused by new trig implementations in Chrome Canary.

issue.title: Don’t output points at exactly -180° when clipping.

repository.name: d3
repository.description: Bring data to life with SVG, Canvas and HTML. :bar_chart::chart_with_upwards_trend::tada:

issue.body:
Previously, we were generating points along the antimeridian at λ=±180°
when clipping.  Strictly speaking, on a sphere, -180° is the same
longitude as +180°.  Internally, we can distinguish these “coincident”
points and preserve the longitude’s sign when converting to and from
Cartesian coordinates by assuming that atan2(sin(±π), x<0)=±π.

Up until now, this has worked, probably due to floating point roundoff
in Math.PI meaning that abs(λ) < π, and hence sin(±Math.PI) is a very
small non-zero number, effectively preserving the sign of the longitude.

It seems Chrome Canary has added some minor approximations, which
improve performance but bring to light our reliance on this behaviour,
since sin(+Math.PI) = sin(-Math.PI) = +0.  Strictly speaking, I think
Chrome should return -0 for sin(-Math.PI), but we probably shouldn’t
rely on it, as it’s not in ECMAScript.

I had already made a minor modification to avoid generating these
“coincident” points in the clip-polygon branch.  I decided longitudes
should be in the range [-180°, +180°), and thus points were output with
longitudes -π and π - ε.  This was required to fix various issues with
handling of coincident points elsewhere.

In Chrome, this modification doesn’t actually fix the problem, because
atan2(sin(-π), x)=π where x<0, so λ=-180° becomes λ=+180° when
resampling.  Instead, the range (-180, +180°] does in fact fix the
issue, using λ=ε-π and λ=π.  As I mentioned above, it would be nice if
Chrome’s implementation gave atan2(sin(-Math.PI), x<0)=-Math.PI.

For good measure, I’ve enforced this in d3.geo.rotation too, ensuring
that input points with λ<ε-π become λ=+π.

We could go further and output points at abs(λ)=π-ε, but it seems
unnecessary as the above already preserves the longitude’s sign.

Note: I haven’t updated any tests for this change.

Fixes #1635.

issue.title: user "home location" map: not recording proper coordinates on click

repository.name: openstreetmap-website
repository.description: The Rails application that powers OpenStreetMap

issue.body:
**Moving from https://github.com/openstreetmap/openstreetmap-website/issues/318#issuecomment-28538967**

While testing the OSM.org redesign branch, I found funky behavior in this "home location" selector map. It's actually an issue in master, too: 

![osm-user-home-location](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/212369/1552739/c3b51d0e-4e28-11e3-952a-fa71fe7adcef.gif)

Perhaps the combo of 7db11805066f619f5e2bb99687bb5710a337fd10 and 58eb17c means the precision is now being clipped incorrectly?

For what it's worth I'm on Chrome 32 on a Mac.
